question.title: Is it faster to calculate integer exponentiation with binary or ternary chunks?
question.body:
Code 1

In code one we are using the binary exponentiation.

public class Solution {
    public int pow(int A, int B, int C) {
        if (C == 1) return 0;
        long base = (A % C + C) % C;
        return (int) modPow3(base, B, C);
    }
    private long modPow3(long A, int B, int C) {
        if (B == 0) return 1;
        long part = modPow3(A, B / 2, C);
        long ans = part;
        ans = (ans * part) % C;
        if(B % 2 == 1) {
            ans = (ans * A) % C;
        }
        return (int)ans;
    }

}

Code 2

In code two, we use ternary exponentiation. Although this reduces the number of recursive levels because the exponent is divided by 3.

public class Solution {
    public int pow(int A, int B, int C) {
        if (C == 1) return 0;
        long base = (A % C + C) % C;
        return (int) modPow3(base, B, C);
    }
    private long modPow3(long A, int B, int C) {
        if (B == 0) return 1;
        long part = modPow3(A, B / 3, C);
        long ans = part;
        ans = (ans * part) % C;
        ans = (ans * part) % C;
        if(B % 3 == 1) {
            ans = (ans * A) % C;
        }
        else if(B % 3 == 2) {
            ans = (ans * A) % C;
            ans = (ans * A) % C;
        }
        return (int)ans;
    }
}
